summary: This document is an email chain from May 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing how to handle Touhy requests (requests for government information) from civil plaintiffs/victims related to Jeffrey Epstein. It reveals internal coordination, jurisdictional complexities regarding materials from the Southern District of Florida (SDFL) investigation, and strategic decisions on information disclosure.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney at Kaplan Hecker & Fink representing an Epstein victim/plaintiff in a civil suit, to whom the SDNY plans to send a Touhy request procedure letter.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.context: Referred to as the 'responsible' U.S. Attorney who might receive a Touhy-referred subpoena from another district regarding Epstein materials.

connections.description: Kaplan is legal counsel representing a victim who is a plaintiff in a civil suit against Epstein's estate, as indicated by the Touhy request.

events.title: Production of documents to Epstein victim
events.description: The SDNY produced documents responsive to an Epstein victim's Touhy request about a month prior, and the requester followed up with additional questions.

events.title: Decision on handling further Touhy requests
events.description: SDNY staff decide on a plan to tell requesters they do not have SDFL investigation materials and to direct them to SDFL or NDGA, and to not produce further materials from the ongoing investigation.

keyFacts: The SDNY possesses FBI investigative files from the SDFL Epstein investigation but deliberately avoided obtaining any files from the U.S. Attorney's Office in SDFL due to conflict issues, discovery issues, and to avoid appearing to step into the shoes of a district bound by a prior non-prosecution agreement.

SDNY staff explicitly state they have no materials relating to purported immunity discussions for potential co-conspirators, assuming any such discussions were between defense counsel and the SDFL USAO.
The Northern District of Georgia (NDGA) has 'stepped into the shoes' of SDFL for Epstein-related matters, indicating a transfer of jurisdictional responsibility.

The email chain reveals internal debate and uncertainty about the proper procedure under Touhy regulations for referring requesters to another U.S. Attorney's Office, highlighting the complex inter-district coordination in the Epstein case.
A grand jury subpoena was previously disclosed to a victim (Jane Doe) and was considered for production again in response to her Touhy request.
